headline.main: State Is in Forefront of Changing Drug Laws

docs.abstract: Connecticut emerges as innovator, as state govts experiment with drug law reform; state is one of first to allow needle-exchange programs, and Connecticut is beginning to allow convicted drug offenders or criminals whose crimes are result of alcohol or drug abuse to avoid prison time on condition they undergo frequent testing for drug or alcohol abuse; state is expanding its drug court system, which monitors drug offenders' efforts to rehabilitate themselves, and thse courts will be arbiters of new of new policy (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: AS state governments experiment with drug law reform, Connecticut is emerging as an innovator. The state was one of the first to allow needle-exchange programs, which offer intravenous drug users clean syringes in exchange for used ones. Such programs were started in Connecticut in 1988, after they were shown to be effective in slowing the spread of AIDS, said David D. Biklen, executive director of the Connecticut Law Revision Commission, which researches drug and substance-abuse issues and drug policy options, and makes recommendations to the General Assembly's public health committee. Connecticut is beginning allowing convicted drug offenders or criminals whose crimes are the result of alcohol or drug abuse to avoid prison time on the condition they undergo frequent testing for drug or alcohol abuse. (The state is said to be the first to do so.)
